) Correspondex (CRX) is a sub-system of the IDRS (Integrated Data Retrieval System). CRX send letters to taxpayers, other government agencies, tax and titioners and so on. We provide over

national “C-letters” to ﬁt every situation. These letters give you, the IDRS user, the ﬂexibility to choose from selective paragraphs, and create numerous “Fill-ins” to communicate accu- rately and professionally. (

) When you use the Correspondex System, the IDRS mainframe will • automatically post an Entity-History-Record to the taxpayer’s account the Taxpayer Information File (TIF) • print a duplicate copy of the letter for the Power of Attorney, if any • print a duplicate copy of the letter for the Taxpayer’s spouse if he/she lives at different address. • automatically print the taxpayer’s mailing address • sign your manager’s name to the letter • generate the correct return address • print your letter on a high speed laser printer. (
) Other programs in the IDRS system work with Correspondex to provide you with an on-line Quality Review, (see IRM
) and establish a security trail. (

) Some Correspondex users also have the option of using the “Correspondex Expert System,” one of the ﬁrst Artiﬁcial Intelligence programs developed at IRS. This provides all the features listed above with some up-to-date PC software for those who prefer it. (Instructions for using the Expert System are published separately.) (
) Our command codes are programs that work in IDRS real time to initiate (Correspondex) letters. There are now six. (

) LETER retrieves name and address data from the TIF or the National Proﬁle (NAP) or the CRRSPNDX-NON-LETTER-FIILE (CNLF). It then builds the CC LPAGE screen with the necessary tab-stops, protected ﬁelds, and screen prompts. • Enter CC LETER with a Taxpayer Identiﬁcation Number (TIN), and necessary information. CC LETER will check the user’s IDRS production/training mode against the requested TIN to protect data accessed by unauthorized users. If the security check is passed, the TIF is searched for the related name and address. If the TIN is not located on the TIF, or if there are no address lines, CC LETER checks the NAP. If the account is not on the NAP, CC LETER generates the LPAGE screen with the name and address lines left blank. If CC ﬁnds a match, it builds an LPAGE screen with the name and address the proper ﬁelds. CC LETER selects Taxpayer name lines based on following criteria: • For domestic address, up to four name lines are displayed on the CC LPAGE screen if the TIF account has more than one name line. • For foreign address, all name lines on the TIF account are selected. If more than one name line is manually entered on the CC LPAGE the print program also applies these criteria to print name lines on the ﬁnished letter. (

Enter CC LETER with a Taxpayer Identiﬁcation Number (TIN), and necessary information. If the account is not on the NAP, CC LETER generates the LPAGE screen with the name and address lines left blank. If CC ﬁnds a match, it builds an LPAGE screen with the name and address in the proper ﬁelds. CC LETER selects Taxpayer name lines based on the following criteria: For domestic address, up to four name lines are displayed on the CC LPAGE screen if the TIF account has more than one name line. For foreign address, all name lines on the TIF account are selected. If more than one name line is manually entered on the CC LPAGE the print program also applies these criteria to print name lines on the ﬁnished letter.

Command Codes LETER, LPAGE, LPAGD, LETUP, LETED, LLIST, and LREVW 2.4.6 page 3
LREVW

) This is another tool to improve the quality of outgoing correspondence. To CC LREVW, set the “View” indicator on the CC LPAGE screen to “Y” and transmit. CC LREVW will be automatically executed for you. CC LREVW combines the Selective paragraph codes, ﬁll-in content, and other optional entries you made on the LPAGE screen with the form letter you selected the Master Letter File. The program operates like the end-of-day program, CRX
, and formats the letter with headings, salutations,
character print lines, and even page breaks identical to those used on the ﬁnal letter. However, where CRX

prints the letter on paper, CC LREVW will do it on your terminal screen. Your ﬁll-ins will be highlighted with inverse video, so will easily be able to see if you made any errors. The paragraphs you will be printed out completely. You can even see the name and title of the person you selected with your Signature Title code. After you have reviewed your letter, return to page one and make any corrections. When you are satisﬁed with your letter, set the “View” indicator to “N” and transmit CC LPAGE to send your letter. (

) CC LPAGD — Use this command code to delete a letter request input the same day’s real-time processing. The same employee who input the original letter request must input the LPAGD using the same TIN, Tax Period, Plan Number, and Form Letter Number. All these ﬁelds, the input Employee Number must match or the letter request will not be deleted, and a taxpayer letter will be generated. For July
, LPAGD will check the letter pending database to make sure a letter was produced in the day. (

) CC LETUP/LETED— These command codes help the Service Center Letter Technicians deal with special situations. Use CC LETUP followed by a form letter number to bring up a display showing the status of three special ﬁelds the CLVF. a. Restrict-Availability-Indicator. Use CC LETED to set the ﬁrst indicator “Y” to make a particular form letter unavailable. This might be handy if you detect errors in the letter, and do not want it used until corrections can be made. b. Bypass-QR-Indicator. Set the second ﬁeld to “Y” if Service Center agement wishes a particular form letter to bypass Quality Review and printed immediately. You could use this for your acknowledgement or “Selected” letters. c. Number-of-Copies. The number of copies to the taxpayer and or the Power of attorney (POA) should never exceed an original and one See IRM
Correspondence. (

CC LPAGD — Use this command code to delete a letter request input during the same day’s real-time processing. The same employee who input the original letter request must input the LPAGD using the same TIN, MFT-CODE, Tax Period, Plan Number, and Form Letter Number. All these ﬁelds, including the input Employee Number must match or the letter request will not be deleted, and a taxpayer letter will be generated. For July

, LPAGD will check the letter pending database to make sure a letter was produced earlier in the day. ) LLIST can be used to research whether a letter was input earlier in the day. Simply enter LLIST and the program will ﬁnd all LPAGE records using LLISTD employee number. If there is more than one screen, ’PAGE’ will be used for display purposes. If the TIN/MFT/TAX PERIOD are entered, then only the LPAGE records for that one account will show. A search may also be done based on employee number. The order of the list will be ’LIFO’ - last in ﬁrst out. (

) LLIST with deﬁner ’D’ can be used to delete individual LPAGE records. This command code should only be used after LLIST and only for deletes. You delete more than one record on the same screen. • The cursor must be below the record you are deleting and above the PAGE prompt. • You cannot delete multiple records that are on different screens. • Keep in mind, this is no different than using LPAGD. Deletes should be done for letters created prior to the GENDATA swap and deletes done after the swap will go on the next day’s QR matches. • Any deletes on duplicates will begin with the last one input and will delete all earlier versions. ) The Artiﬁcial Intelligence Lab has developed an auxiliary to the IDRS Corre- spondex System. For instructions in its use, please see the “Correspondex Expert System Training Manual.” If a letter is created using the Expert SYSTEM (CES) an “E” will appear in line
, column

of the CC LPAGE response screen. Similarly, if it is reviewed using the Expert System, an “R” will appear there, and if it is both created and reviewed with the Expert System, a “B” will appear. These indicators are to help Headquarters programmers trace the source of the letters in the event of questions or problems later, and will not appear in the ﬁnished letter. Letters created using the Expert System should be indistinguishable from those created under the traditional system. (
) SERP (formerly The IDRS Correspondex Document

) contains exhibits the letters that are available for use through IDRS. The exhibit for each letter The shows the information you need to send that particular letter. This information includes the Form Letter number, the Fill-in number for each Fill-in, the

) maximum number of characters allowed for each Fill-in, the validity require- ments for each Fill-in (i.e., whether the characters you key in for the Fill-in have to be all numeric, or all alphabetic, or can be variable, etc.). If a letter is a Pre-addressed letter (that is, it is always sent to the same place— usually another government agency), the exhibit for that letter says so. Selective Paragraph codes identify the optional or “Selective” paragraphs, if any. Each letter, which is an Information Collection Request (ICR), has an Office of Management and Budget (OMB) clearance number and an optional approval expiration date. If the letter is a Returns Perfection (follow-up) letter, one which solely requests information which was omitted from, or incorrectly reported on a previously ﬁled ICR, key in an OMB code during real time. CC LPAGE will use this code to extract the OMB clearance number and date of the Federal Tax Form in question from the CNLF. The OMB Index in the IDRS Correspondex provides a list of Federal Tax Forms and the OMB code associated with each. It also lists the OMB clearance number and expiration date. ) Check the name and address displayed on the screen to ensure it is the correct and complete address for the addressee. If name lines need to be input, remember, only two name lines normally print on the formatted letter. NAME-LINE-
will always print. For the hierarchy of how other name lines selected, and the exceptions, See IRM
) The Salutation for a letter appears on line
of the CC LPAGE screen. • For Pre-addressed letters, leave line

blank. The Salutation for a addressed letter is a ﬁxed and invariable part of the letter format on the IDRS Letter Tape. • For non Pre-addressed letters, CC LETER generates “Taxpayer:” as Salutation. CC LETER does not generate a salutation if there is a TC
(decedent case) or a TC

(deceased taxpayer) on the tax module. • If you prefer a more personalized salutation, you may overlay “Taxpayer:” with the name and gender of the recipient. The computer generates the word “Dear”. Be sure to use proper capitalization, and place a colon (:) at the end of the salutation. The following are examples of appropriate salutations: (Dear) Sirs: (Dear) Mr. Goodfellow III: (Dear) Mr. and Mrs. Oberon: (Dear) Ms. Titania: (

) CAF Indicator — Use this ﬁeld when you know that there is a authorized to receive a taxpayer letter, but the representative is not on the CAF for that particular Service Center. Another use for this ﬁeld is to produce a duplicate letter with a different address without having to enter CC LETER. a. If you enter a “Y”, CC LPAGE returns the CC LPAGEC screen See Exhibit

that allows the input operator to key in the name and address of a known representative not on the CAF. A copy of the er’s letter will be generated with the name and address input on this screen. of this IRM.] When management selects an employee’s transactions for review, there is a delay of up to two business days between the time an employee enters the letter request and the time it is printed in ﬁnal form. If, at any time during period Quality Review accepts the transaction, the letter will print that night. However, if Quality Review has not acted upon the transaction within two business days, the letter prints at the end of the second day. For example, if employee

The response to command code LREVW consists of several pages or screens. Control of the IDRS terminal transfers to command code PAGE. Page 001 of the response is always a facsimile of the original LPAGE you just transmitted with the view indicator set to “N”. (If the prior command code QRACN, the default view indicator is “?”.) The formatted letter begins on Page 002. To see the formatted letter, transmit through the various pages, or screens. Remember that an IDRS screen contains 24 lines of the formatted letter. The printed letter will contain 60 lines per page so there are about two and one-half screens per page. Letter page breaks are shown with a line of equal signs = = =), so that you will see on the screen how the letter will actually appear on paper.
Exhibit 2.4.6-10 (01-01-2004) Command Code LREVW Respond Screen 2

Here’s a sample of the second screen of output of LREVW. This is how the letter in Exhibit 2.4.7 might look. This is probably a three page letter as it takes six screens to show it all. Note that the ﬁll-ins and the Salutation, if changed, are highlighted with inverse video. This makes it easy for you to spot the places where you may have made a typing or spelling error. Fill-in 02 was a “T” coded ﬁll-in. LPAGE expanded it to the TIN shown above. Fill-in 04 was a “P” coded ﬁll-in. LPAGE picked up the tax period from line 1 of the screen and expanded it.
Due to the inﬁnite variety of possible Letter input, your LREVW screen may look quite different. This is only one possibility.
